PDF Conversion Best Practices

Converting files to PDF format requires careful attention to quality and settings. Here are proven tips to get the best results.

Image to PDF Conversion

When converting images to PDF, consider these factors:

  • Resolution: Use high-resolution images (300 DPI) for print quality
  • Color mode: RGB for digital viewing, CMYK for printing
  • File size: Balance quality with file size for web use

Document to PDF

For document conversions:

  • Font embedding: Ensure fonts are embedded to maintain appearance
  • Page orientation: Check if landscape or portrait is needed
  • Margins: Set appropriate margins for readability

Quality Settings

Choose the right quality settings based on your needs:

  1. High quality: For professional documents and printing
  2. Medium quality: For general web use and sharing
  3. Compressed: For email attachments and storage

Common Conversion Issues

Text Not Selectable

If text becomes unselectable after conversion, the original was likely an image. Use OCR tools for scanned documents.

Poor Image Quality

Low-quality images in PDFs usually result from:

  • Insufficient source image resolution
  • Aggressive compression settings
  • Incorrect color space conversion

Recommended Tools

  • JPG to PDF Converter
  • PNG to PDF Converter
  • PDF to JPG Converter

Pro Tips

  • Always keep original files as backup
  • Test PDFs on different devices and viewers
  • Use consistent naming conventions
  • Consider file size for email attachments
